title: Morbius
description: Dangerously ill with a rare blood disorder, and determined to save others suffering his same fate, Dr. Michael Morbius attempts a desperate gamble. What at first appears to be a radical success soon reveals itself to be a remedy potentially worse than the disease.

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Morbius. The conflict and charcacter development is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of classic English dramatic literature, most of the weight of the scenario will go over a typical viewer's head. There's also Michael’s nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his characterisation- his personal philosophy draws heavily from Narodnaya Volya literature, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these scenes, to realise that they're not only humorous- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence, people who dislike Morbius truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the depth in Morbius’ quote: “I am Venom.  Just kidding, I’m Dr. Michael Morbius at your service.” which itself is a cryptic reference to Turgenev's Russian epic Fathers and Sons. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Jared Leto's genius wit unfolds itself exclusively on the cinematic screens this April 1st. What fools... how I pity them

Morbius does a good job at introducing a character for the sinister six pack that the spiderman universe was inching to have all these years. Although it does not achieve a perfect hitting on all cylinders, the faithful attempt at showcasing dark elements of a blood thirsty creature pays off well. The CGI occassionally gets into the trippy zone where the effects are heavy warranting a better creative direction or polishing. Apart from that, this is a cbm that delivers and offers a blast for those nerds who are into the sinister six comics. The post credits scene only add to the excitement with subtle references to MCU but still largely in the Marvel universe under Sony and which I honestly think needs further world building.

Morbius is one of the more real darker marvel sony film since The New Mutant, and it seems like to be another entertaining Marvel product since No Way Home, what i like the most in Morbius is how they take it so seriously, it's not like the 2018 Venom movie which still have more humor than the serious thing, and of course Let There Be Carnage which is basically a jokes in literally every second of it, Morbius is 95% a real dark serious movie with a dark background story that played so well by Jared Leto and Matt Smith, Leto did a way fantastic job than Smith but he still great too, the movie is also a cinematically stunning film, everytime they did the slow-mo action shot i was amazed by it because it's a cool thing to do and i'm pretty sure people will make that as a problem but i found it to be awesome, i throughly enjoy the whole action scene including the final fight, i though it was amazing, the score was absolutely incredible, i'm not bored throughout the film, it feels fast, and overall i did really like Morbius, now it isn't a perfect movie, there is still a lot of flawed in here, including the movie have one of the worst kissing scene i've ever seen in movies, and they've done it twice, there is a one dance sequence in the film that is just horrible or more of like cringe to watch, there is a flashback scene in the beginning of the film that i found it to be very lame, and probably Milo vampire CGI face was just not as great as Jared Leto Morbius make up and CGI, and that's about it, thankfully there is still more of a good thing in Morbius in my opinion than the bad thing and overall Morbius is still a hell of a movie, it's simply one of the most entertaining films of the year.

The movie was badly cut due to Sony/Disney deal which resulted in preventing showing all the Spider-Man easter eggs. If one wants to blame someone - Disney must be blamed for putting their hands on Spider-Man after the initial 6-movie deal with Sony. Regarding the movie itself - the story wasn't much gripping but for the first depiction of an anti-hero it was just okay - not too boring to fall asleep, but not thrilling either. There was good acting from Jared Leto and Matt Smith. The best part of the movie was nice looking and eye-catching cinematography. The visual effects were decent, not too bad - satisfying. Brilliant music throughout the whole movie. The 3rd movie of the Sony's Spider-Man certainly is worse than the previous two, but overall it was a good watch.

The comic book adaptation is pretty good! I can explain. First, it is an anti-hero comic book character. And although it keeps most of the vampire blood-sucking gags, it's dark, not cheesy, and a good sideshow to sink your teeth into! Now, on the other end, the so-called critics and people that get drunk off of defiling art by talking about the CGI but, obviously, never skimmed through the comic - should be ashamed to know that Sony did the right thing by implementing Morbius's purple hue within his rapid motion. It is purposefully, not "cheap" or "lazy" animation! You can always tell when a student comes to class and didn't do the homework but pretends to act as though they did. In today's world of quick Google searches, you got phony professional or amateur critics that draw deductions on emotions rather than putting in the arduous hard work. It's such an oxymoron to refer to the animation as "cheap" and "lazy" without knowing the historical art style of the comic. It's always those who never do their homework that grossly chastises what they know little about. It psychologically proves that these very people are not only toxic and untrustworthy but live a life of lies.
